author: By Katie Kitamura
title: No Place Is Home, for the Immigrant Hero of This Debut Novel
description: “Hangman,” by Maya Binyam, follows the narrator on a disorienting trip back to his native country.
content: A man receives a phone call and is given instructions to board a flight. His bag has been packed, his ticket is in the pocket of his jacket and a car is waiting outside. It is only on the plane that he discovers he is bound for “the country I had left 26 years prior,” a fact that leaves him “neither happy nor unhappy.” A man by and large without preferences, conditioned into passivity, he is propelled deeper and deeper into a story of surreal recognition and misrecognition in Maya Binyam’s exceptional debut novel, “Hangman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: The Big Ten Lands Oregon and Washington, Leaving the Pac-12 Bereft
description: The Big Ten booms to 18 schools with the move, powered by TV money, and the once-great Pac-12 dwindles to four after three more schools leave for the Big 12.
content: Two weeks ago, George Kliavkoff, the commissioner of the Pac-12 Conference, stood on a Las Vegas nightclub stage and — after a video montage celebrating the league’s rich history of star quarterbacks that runs to the present — confidently proclaimed a bright future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Palestinian Kills Israeli in Tel Aviv, a Day After West Bank Violence
description: A gunman from Jenin, West Bank, shot and killed an Israeli security guard on Saturday. It came the evening after a Palestinian was killed in a fight with Israeli settlers.
content: A Palestinian gunman shot and killed an Israeli security guard in central Tel Aviv on Saturday evening, in what the Israeli police described as a terrorist attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Killer Asteroid-Spotting Software Could Help Save the World
description: HelioLinc3D, which was developed for the Vera Rubin Observatory in Chile, showed its potential after finding an overlooked space rock that will make a close path of Earth.
content: The ability of technology to solve global problems is often overhyped. But when it comes to saving the world from asteroid strikes, lines of code may prove to be our savior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Does the Future of Summer Look Like for You?
description: We want to hear from you.
content: This summer has brought one extreme weather event after the next. Smoke from wildfires in Canada has swept into cities across the United States. A recent storm dropped as much as nine inches of rain in parts of Vermont, leading to catastrophic flooding. For 31 straight days, Phoenix reached or surpassed 110 degrees, yet another extreme weather event fueled by climate change. For some people, this has felt like a defining summer, though it has felt different depending on where they live in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Eight Fights
description: Nadia’s family is split between Russia and Ukraine. Right now, that’s complicated.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mac Schwerin
title: Is This the End of the Summer Vacation as We Know It?
description: This year, everything from scorching heat to fires, floods, tornadoes and hail storms driven by climate change have disrupted the plans of travelers around the world. A summer getaway remains a powerful desire, but it’s at a tipping point.
content: You can’t escape the orange. That’s what travelers this summer have been reckoning with — swaths of tangerine, traffic cone and burnt sienna on maps indicating record high temperatures around the globe. Four concurrent heat domes from the southern United States to East Asia descended on millions — Phoenix residents enduring 31 days of 110-degree-plus temperatures. Italians in more than a dozen cities under extreme weather warnings. And in South Korea, at least 125 people were hospitalized for heat-related conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: In a Reversal, A.P. Psychology May Be Allowed in Florida Schools After All
description: The College Board and the Florida Department of Education had been feuding over the inclusion of a section on gender and sexual orientation.
content: Students in Florida may be permitted to take Advanced Placement Psychology in the coming school year, officials said on Friday, a day after the College Board had revoked its support for the course in Florida, asserting that it had been “effectively banned” by the state’s Department of Education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Leland
title: I Have a Choice to Make About My Blindness
description: The feeling of shared experience that comes when two people interact and exchange ideas and abilities is something technology can’t provide.
content: I recently visited a local Mexican restaurant with my family. It was the first time we’d gone out together for a meal since the start of the pandemic. As I gazed up at the familiar menu boards hanging behind the counter, I realized with some dismay that I could no longer read them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Ransomware Attack Disrupts Health Care Services in at Least Three States
description: It was not immediately clear how many locations operated by Prospect Medical Holdings were affected but some sites had to cut back services or close.
content: A ransomware attack this week on a California-based health care system forced some of its locations to close and left others to rely on paper records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Florence Berger, Who Helped People Find Enduring Love, Dies at 83
description: A tenured professor at Cornell with a feel for human chemistry, she found a second calling as a successful matchmaker. Almost all of her pairings lasted.
content: Florence Berger, a Cornell University professor who found a second calling as a pro bono matchmaker, leading her to successfully arrange some two dozen marriages, died on July 13 at her home in Charlottesville, Va. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: The Women’s Magazines of 2023 Are in a Facebook Group and Your Inbox
description: People still want to know what to wear and what is actually worth buying — and they want to trust the person telling them.
content: What should a 33-year-old postpartum woman wear to her cousin’s 21st birthday party in New York City?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Some Wells Fargo Customer Deposits Disappear Because of a ‘Technical Issue’
description: Reports of a processing error began to surface on Thursday and continued through Friday. Wells Fargo said on Saturday that the issue had been resolved.
content: Some Wells Fargo customers checked their bank accounts this week to discover that their recent deposits had disappeared, causing them to express concern over where the money had gone and, in some cases, to report being late on their bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bridgette Bartlett Royall
title: What They Paid for Their Weddings
description: Former brides reveal where they splurged and where they scrimped for their nuptials — and what (if anything) they would have done differently.
content: One couple spent less than $2,000 for an intimate wedding at a local hotel. Another paid $200,000 for an elaborate out-of-town affair. We asked six married women to share how much they spent on their weddings — and where they felt the money was well-spent, where it was wasted and what they wish they had done differently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Tiffany May
title: Their Rooftop Photos Are Stunning. Their Subculture Has Its Critics.
description: “Rooftoppers” get a thrill from taking photos atop skyscrapers and sharing them on social media. Detractors call them reckless.
content: Remi Lucidi, a sergeant in the French Army, died far from a battlefield. His body was found last week aside a Hong Kong skyscraper where he had been spotted near the rooftop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Big Tech Rebounds and Preps for Transformative A.I. Investments
description: As the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on artificial intelligence, which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.
content: A year ago, the tech industry’s prospects looked bleak. Google’s profit dropped. Shares of Facebook’s parent company, Meta, were in free fall. Business growth at Amazon had slowed to its lowest level in two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 29-Aug. 4
description: To reach Genius, you had to milk this week’s toughest word for all it was worth.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Henri Konan Bédié, Ivory Coast President Deposed in a Coup, Dies at 89
description: As a longtime power broker he helped make his West African country an economic dynamo, but in office he fomented ethnic divisions and cracked down on dissent.
content: Henri Konan Bédié, who served as president of Ivory Coast from 1993 until being deposed in a coup in 1999, but who remained a power broker among its often violently competitive political and ethnic factions, died on Tuesday in Abidjan, the country’s largest city. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Normal Paths to Beating Trump Are Closing
description: How the indictments are making it harder to fight 2024 on any grounds except Trump’s fitness.
content: In the quest to escape Donald Trump’s dominance of American politics, there have been two camps: normalizers and abnormalizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: The Loss of Space Command Headquarters Brings an Alabama City Down to Earth
description: Huntsville, a city with a proud history of aerospace innovation, was set to welcome Space Command, until a distant force beyond its control intervened: politics.
content: Even as a child in the 1960s, Jan Davis felt a twinge of resentment about her hometown, Huntsville, Ala., being overlooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert
title: Battle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 Days
description: In addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets.
content: A Ukrainian maritime drone packed with explosives rammed into a Russian oil tanker early Saturday off the eastern coast of occupied Crimea, Russian officials and a Ukrainian official said, the second strike on a Russian ship at sea in two days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Catastrophe of Dam’s Destruction, a Trove of Artifacts Is Revealed
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 5, 2023.
content: “We’re finding pieces of ancient culture, our ancient culture. Piece by piece, we’re distancing ourselves from Russia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Hvistendahl, David A. Fahrenthold, Lynsey Chutel and Ishaan Jhaveri
title: A Global Web of Chinese Propaganda Leads to a U.S. Tech Mogul
description: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
content: The protest in London’s bustling Chinatown brought together a variety of activist groups to oppose a rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So it was peculiar when a street brawl broke out among mostly ethnic Chinese demonstrators.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Save American Theater
description: Readers, several in the theater business, offer laments and suggestions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Texas Judge Says Doctors Can Use ‘Good Faith Judgment’ in Providing Abortions
description: The ruling sought to clarify the medical exceptions in the state’s bans, and was in a response to a lawsuit from women who were denied abortions despite medical emergencies.
content: A Texas judge ruled on Friday that the state must allow doctors to provide abortions to pregnant women whose health or lives are in danger, or whose fetuses have little likelihood of survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: She’s One of the Fastest Women Ever. All She’s Missing Is a Gold Medal.
description: Marie-Josée Ta Lou of Ivory Coast has been milliseconds away from the top of Olympic and World Championship podium stands. She has a chance at redemption this month in Budapest.
content: Marie-Josée Ta Lou has often been unlucky on days when she needed to be perfect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Legal Team Is Enmeshed in a Tangle of Possible Conflicts
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s growing cast of lawyers is marked by a web of overlapping interests encompassing witnesses, co-defendants and potential targets.
content: M. Evan Corcoran, a lawyer who accompanied former President Donald J. Trump to court this week for his arraignment on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election, has given crucial evidence in Mr. Trump’s other federal case — the one accusing him of illegally hoarding classified documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Your Next Great Meal
description: Having a hard time keeping up with all your dining options? Here are some tips.
content: If you’re the type of person, as I am, who likes to try new restaurants as much as possible, keeping up can be tough. That’s especially true in a city as rich and diverse as New York, which I cover in my weekly restaurant newsletter for The Times’s Food section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Nehamas
title: On the Campaign Trail, an Impossible Task: Ignoring Trump’s Latest Charges
description: Voters pressed them to weigh in. Reporters asked about pardons. Mike Pence was heckled. Republicans found it’s not easy to escape the fallout from Donald J. Trump’s legal peril.
content: Days after the front-runner was indicted on charges of trying to subvert an election, Republican candidates in their presidential primary returned to the campaign trail acting as if nothing had changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: A Shrinking Footprint in Africa for France, the Former Colonizer That Stayed
description: A recent military takeover in Niger has thrown into uncertainty the future of France’s presence in West and Central Africa, raising doubts about the future of U.S. military involvement there, too.
content: The country’s president, a trusted ally of France, was taken hostage in the presidential palace by his own guards in late July. Protesters massed at the French Embassy soon after, setting it on fire and shattering windows. A colonel in uniform appeared late Thursday on state television and announced that the military was ending its cooperation with France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: This Is the Music America Needs
description: I recently spent two days with Gangstagrass, a band that is making music that creates social cohesion, not division.
content: Predictably, Jason Aldean’s song “Try That in a Small Town” jumped to the top of the charts days after liberals accused it of promoting vigilantism and racism. Reasonable people can disagree about whether that was Mr. Aldean’s intent, but this much is clear: When half the country condemns something, the other half rushes to praise it. The free publicity, complete with an online post by Donald Trump, spurred a surge in record sales. In this polarized era, division sells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: For Mayor Adams, Any Day Has the Makings of Flag Day
description: From Belgium to the Bahamas, Mayor Eric Adams has raised the flags of at least 31 countries since taking office, a civic gesture with political benefits.
content: On any given weekday, there is a statistically significant chance that Eric Adams, the mayor of America’s largest city, will be conducting official New York City business next to the upturned tail of the famed “Charging Bull” sculpture, engaging in what appears to be one of his favorite activities: raising flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: World Cup Picks Up Baton for Women’s Sports in Australia
description: For as long as there have been sports in Australia, women have clamored to play and participate. But winning visibility, and support, has been a long road.
content: Fans celebrated in central Melbourne this week after a national triumph: The Matildas, the Australian women’s soccer team, had defeated Canada, the reigning Olympic champion, 4-0.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Chambers
title: A Love Letter to Hip-Hop
description: Hip-hop repeatedly taught a community, then a nation, then the world, how to dream.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Ukrainians Dismayed as Pope Declines to Condemn Russia at World Youth Day
description: “It’s not enough just to listen — he has to do something,” said Dmytro Bohak, one of about 500 young Ukrainian pilgrims who attended the event and staged a demonstration.
content: On Friday afternoon, some of the hundreds of thousands of young Roman Catholic pilgrims filing into a park in Lisbon to pray with Pope Francis stopped to embrace their Ukrainian peers standing on a small hill, holding blue-and-yellow flags and wearing black shirts featuring the faces of children killed in Russia’s invasion of their country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Police Arrest 7 Over Murder Threats at Seoul Subway Stations
description: Posts online in the wake of recent stabbing assaults specified sites for copycat attacks. They prompted swift police action in a nation rattled by the random violence.
content: After a car rampage and two stabbings in and around the South Korean capital that shocked the nation in the past month, at least seven people have been arrested on suspicion of making threats to carry out similar acts, the police said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Luxury Vantage Point
description: John Guzzetta returns with a high-flying Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really quick-witted themeless puzzle. It has enough challenges to make it satisfying to get through, and the funny bits that are sprinkled throughout make it a pleasure to solve. John Guzzetta has constructed for The New York Times for over a decade, and he has hit for the cycle, meaning he has created at least one puzzle for every day of the week, although most of them are Friday and Saturday grids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan Sentenced to Prison, Likely Dashing Hopes of Political Comeback
description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was taken into custody, sentenced to three years after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets.
content: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was arrested on Saturday after a trial court sentenced him to three years in prison, a verdict likely to end his chances of running in upcoming general elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Spain, With Flourishes, Bounds Into Quarterfinals
description: Spain has been one of the strongest teams in the tournament. Next, it will play either the Netherlands or South Africa.
content: When you think about it, even the own goal was impressive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Who Threatened Arizona Election Officials Gets More Than 3 Years in Prison
description: The man called for a mass shooting of poll workers and also threatened the families of two county officials, saying that someone needed to get “these people and their children.”
content: A man who called for a “mass shooting of poll workers” and threatened two Arizona county officials and their families over the 2022 election was sentenced on Thursday to three and a half years in federal prison, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Fu
title: Is It Possible to Buy a House in Your 20s? Yes, but Only With Some Help.
description: For some young people, a path to homeownership often involves a mix of diligent saving combined with assistance from family or government loans and programs.
content: Last year, while Whitney Buehler was in Croatia on her honeymoon, the back of her mind was home in Atlanta gearing up for a summer of house hunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Charles J. Ogletree Jr., 70, Dies; at Harvard Law, a Voice for Equal Justice
description: A mentor to the Obamas and many others, he was renowned for his work in both the classroom and the courtroom, taking cases on behalf of the famous and the indigent alike.
content: Charles J. Ogletree Jr., a Harvard law professor who helped reframe debates around criminal justice, school desegregation and reparations during the 1990s and 2000s, all the while mentoring a new generation of Black lawyers that included President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, died on Friday at his home in Odenton, Md. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Berkshire Hathaway Posts Quarterly Profit of Nearly $36 Billion
description: A rebound in performance at the Geico car insurer helped offset declines in the conglomerate’s freight railroad business.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate led by the billionaire Warren Buffett, posted its highest ever quarterly operating profit on Saturday, while gains from stock holdings helped Berkshire swing to an overall profit of nearly $36 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: How a Sexual Assault in a School Bathroom Became a Political Weapon
description: It was an explosive claim — that a Virginia school district covered up a crime in order to protect transgender rights. But was it true?
content: For months a sort of aerosolized fury had hung over the Loudoun County school district. There were fights over Covid closures and mask mandates, over racial-equity programs, over library books. Now, in the weeks before the school board’s meeting on June 22, 2021, attention had shifted to a new proposal: Policy 8040, which would let transgender students choose pronouns, play sports and use bathrooms in accordance with their declared gender identity. In May, an elementary-school gym teacher announced that as a “servant of God,” he felt he could not follow the policy. The district swiftly suspended him — and just as swiftly, the antennae of conservative media outlets and politicians swiveled toward Loudoun County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Brill
title: The Country Will Only Believe the Trump Verdict if They Can See It
description: Imagine how televised access to the quiet, methodical presentation of both sides’ arguments might temper the national mood when the verdict is announced.
content: The only issue that Americans on all sides of our vast political divide seem to agree on is that we cannot agree on anything. Even basic facts have become matters of opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel and Stephen Hiltner
title: A New Frontier for Travel Scammers: A.I.-Generated Guidebooks
description: Shoddy guidebooks are flooding Amazon. Their authors claim to be renowned travel writers, but are they A.I. inventions? And how big is the problem?
content: In March, as she planned for an upcoming trip to France, Amy Kolsky, an experienced international traveler who lives in Bucks County, Pa., visited Amazon.com and typed in a few search terms: travel, guidebook, France. Titles from a handful of trusted brands appeared near the top of the page: Rick Steves, Fodor’s, Lonely Planet. Also among the top search results was the highly rated “France Travel Guide,” by Mike Steves, who, according to an Amazon author page, is a renowned travel writer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Tabery
title: A Revolution Is Coming to Medicine. Who Will It Leave Out?
description: The hype around personalized medicine is distracting us from alternatives that are better suited to improving health for all.
content: On Aug. 16, 2011, my father woke up and couldn’t get out of bed. Until then, he was an avid outdoorsman, who cast for trout on the Delaware River and trained German wirehaired pointers to track and point pheasant. So after an ambulance ride to the emergency room and then hours of tests, the diagnosis shook our family: Stage 4 non-small cell lung cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Where Are the Big Ideas for New York City?
description: The resurrection of the greatest city in the world requires grit and ingenuity.
content: People like to write off New York City, and time and again, this city proves them wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Still Dreaming of Retirement in the Sun Belt?
description: As climate change sends summer temperatures soaring, older people are increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses in places like Phoenix.
content: In 2015, when Diana and Charles Cox were considering where to retire, they drove their R.V. across the Southwest to visit several possibilities: Santa Fe, Sedona, Phoenix, Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Thousands of Scouts Are Leaving Heat-Plagued Jamboree Early
description: The British, Singaporean and U.S. scouting organizations cited health concerns for their departure from a much-anticipated youth event in South Korea.
content: The scout motto is “Be prepared.” But the 25th World Scout Jamboree, taking place as South Korea endures unusually hot weather, has prompted criticism of the event’s organizers, including scouting organization officials and the national government, for their seeming failure to follow that dictum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and Raúl Vilchis
title: They Make Some of New York’s Best Food. They Want the Right to Sell It.
description: New York City officials cracked down on Corona Plaza, a celebrated Queens hub for Latin American street vendors. Its merchants are fighting to legitimize their businesses.
content: Until last week, Corona Plaza in Queens was bustling: taqueros flipping fresh tortillas and vendors hawking Central American crafts over a soundtrack of cumbia and train traffic. There were produce stands, live bands and surging crowds, all in a public square that was named one of the 100 best places to eat in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Lacey
title: A Swedish Fever Dream of Literature and Love, Lost and Found
description: In Ia Genberg’s “The Details,” the unnamed narrator spends the duration of an illness reflecting on her bygone relationships.
content: Serious readers, after decades of filling their shelves, often notice that “some books stay in your bones long after their titles and details have slipped from memory.” The unnamed narrator of Ia Genberg’s brief and penetrating new novel, “The Details,” is just such a reader, haunted by the nearly forgotten minutiae of the novels — and people — that have changed her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Key Witness Doesn’t Back Up G.O.P.’s Biggest Allegations on Bidens
description: The testimony of Devon Archer, a Hunter Biden associate, paints an unflattering portrait of Hunter’s business dealings, but contradicts reports of bribes or material involvement by the president.
content: Republicans who for months have accused President Biden without proof of crime and corruption thought that a former business partner of his son’s could be the key to finally substantiating their most serious allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Chose Their Fate When They Chose to Shield Trump
description: No candidate is coming close to defeating him in the primaries.
content: It’s not too much to say that the 2024 Republican presidential primary is effectively over. In fact, it’s been over. The earliest you could say it was over was Jan. 7, 2021, when most Republican politicians closed ranks around Donald Trump in the wake of the insurrection. The next earliest date was Feb. 13 of the same year, when the majority of Senate Republicans voted to acquit Trump of all charges in his second impeachment trial, leaving him free to run for office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Anne Nguyen
title: I Put On Lipstick for This?
description: Lunch with an older friend prompts a writer to try some seemingly outdated stratagems for attracting a mate.
content: I don’t usually wear lipstick. Or heels. Or pants with zippers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler, Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: ‘Vindicating’: An Analyst Who Lowered the U.S.’s Credit Rating in 2011 on Fitch’s Downgrade
description: Nikola Swann played a key role at S&P when the agency became the first to strip America of its top ranking in 2011.
content: When Nikola Swann heard that Fitch Ratings had removed the United States from its list of risk-free borrowers this week, he felt a sense of satisfaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: What Mike Epps Learned From ‘Sanford and Son’
description: The star of the Netflix sitcom “The Upshaws” borrowed some of his comedic timing from Redd Foxx and was inspired to act from watching Denzel Washington.
content: When Mike Epps was growing up in Indianapolis, his grandmother’s house was home base for the entire family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Which Repairs Are the Co-op’s Responsibility, and Which Are Mine?
description: Start by reading your co-op’s proprietary lease, then move on to city law.
content: Q: We live in a co-op in Midtown East. In the past few months, the amount of cold water in our shower has diminished. The super had the tiles behind the bathroom sink removed to gain access to a water valve, which he said would fix the problem. But it’s worse now — a scalding hot shower or no shower at all — and I’m told that repairing it will entail breaking and removing the tiles in the shower. But this time, we will have to pay for the plumbing and tile work. We feel that providing shower water is the building’s responsibility and that the co-op should cover the cost. What are our rights in this situation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Truth About Your Bacon
description: Newly released videos by undercover investigators underscore the abuse of hogs on factory farms.
content: We used to raise hogs on our family farm here, and to be honest I didn’t much like them. Defenders of farm animals sometimes compare pigs to dogs, but our hogs didn’t display any canine-style affection and instead were grouchy, whiny, strong-willed and prone to wander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: After Transitioning, Gabbi Tuft Pays a Visit to Smackdown
description: She was once a 250-pound gladiator in the World Wrestling Entertainment ring. Now she’s a TikTok star who’s building a new life.
content: Almost until the end, Gabbi Tuft believed she would be able to swing free tickets to World Wrestling Entertainment’s Smackdown at Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Man of the People? Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.
description: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
content: He worked a throng of screaming fans in Dagestan. He hoisted a young girl onto his hip in Kronstadt. He posed shoulder-to-shoulder with seven young siblings, shaking their father’s hand after a naval parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Jan. 6 Prosecutors Ask for Protective Order, Citing Threatening Trump Post
description: In seeking a judge’s order, the government was drawing attention to the former president’s longstanding habit of attacking those involved in criminal cases against him.
content: The federal prosecutors overseeing the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election asked a judge on Friday night to impose a protective order over the discovery evidence in the case, citing a threatening message that Mr. Trump had posted on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Teenager Is Charged in Killing of Dancer at Brooklyn Gas Station
description: He faces a charge of second-degree murder, which has been charged as a hate crime, in the fatal stabbing of Mr. Sibley, a gay man, last week.
content: A 17-year-old has been charged with murder in the killing of O’Shae Sibley, who was stabbed to death on July 29 after a dispute over his dancing at a Brooklyn gas station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Moves Forward With New Tech Tax
description: An international overhaul to tax tech companies is at a standstill, so Canada is forging ahead with another plan.
content: Canada will hang tough on technology companies. That was the message from government officials this week after Meta, the company that owns Facebook and Instagram, began blocking news articles from appearing on its platforms in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Becker and Julie Tate
title: Clarence Thomas’s $267,230 R.V. and the Friend Who Financed It
description: The vehicle is a key part of the justice’s just-folks persona. It’s also a luxury motor coach that was funded by someone else’s money.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas met the recreational vehicle of his dreams in Phoenix, on a November Friday in 1999.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
title: An Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by Side
description: At a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center in the city of Rehovot illustrates the compromises that many Israelis make daily.
content: It was another sweltering Friday in Rehovot, a city in central Israel, and Chaya Hitin and Odelia Tsaidi-Zommer each left their homes for a swim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: How Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Conquered the World
description: The pop star’s record-breaking, career-spanning show has dominated the summer, commanding attention and whipping up demand at a level thought unachievable in a fragmented age.
content: As Taylor Swift rolled into Los Angeles this week, the frenzy surrounding her record-breaking Eras Tour was already in high gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt and Courtney Cox
title: Studying the Limits of Human Perfection, Through Darts
description: Why do athletes always seem to get better, generation by generation? It’s not always for the reasons you might think.
content: Michael Smith, the world’s No. 1-ranked darts player, has won the equivalent of $1.5 million since the start of 2022. In January, he won the World Darts Championship in London, where he achieved the rare feat of nine perfect throws in a row. He says he hasn’t reached the peak of his abilities and is “getting better every year.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: What’s Hanging?
description: Have a seat at the puzzle; Lisa Senzel and Jeff Chen made room.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Coup-Coup-Ca-Choo, Trump-Style
description: Not curtains for Trump the plotter; it’s the entr’acte.
content: WASHINGTON — The man who tried to overthrow the government he was running was held Thursday by the government he tried to overthrow, a few blocks from where the attempted overthrow took place and a stone’s throw from the White House he yearns to return to, to protect himself from the government he tried to overthrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: ‘We Are Feeling Overpoliced’: State Troopers Join Patrols in Austin
description: The city ended a partnership with the Texas Department of Public Safety this month after troubling incidents. In response, Gov. Greg Abbott sent in more troopers.
content: Scores of state highway troopers, usually found on roadways across Texas in their distinctive cowboy hats and black-and-white patrol vehicles, have descended on Austin, the state capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Vivian Nereim and David Pierson
title: Ukraine Starts New Diplomatic Push to Weaken Russia
description: Some 40 countries that have largely remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks on Saturday in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles international efforts to isolate Moscow.
content: Ukraine made a renewed push this weekend at a gathering in Saudi Arabia to win the support of dozens of countries that have remained on the sidelines of the war — the start of a broader campaign in the months ahead to build the diplomatic muscle to isolate and weaken Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How the Artistic Director at SummerStage Spends Her Sundays
description: Rain or shine, Erika Elliott drives from borough to borough to check in on the performances happening in city parks as part of the annual music festival.
content: It is no surprise that Erika Elliott, the executive artistic director at SummerStage, celebrates New York through music.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
content: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Popular Streamer Charged After Giveaway Turns Chaotic in New York
description: Kai Carlo Cenat III, a popular streamer who announced plans to hand out free game consoles at Union Square Park, was charged with inciting a riot after a crowd, estimated at several thousand young people, erupted into mayhem.
content: Kai Carlo Cenat III, a popular streamer who announced plans to hand out free game consoles at Union Square Park, was charged with inciting a riot after a crowd, estimated at several thousand young people, erupted into mayhem.
source.name: The New York Times
